{{Infobox musical artist | name = Virginia Liston | image = | caption = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = 1890 | death_date = June 1932
[[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]], [[Missouri]], [[United States]] | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]] | genre = [[Classic female blues]], [[jazz]] | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = 1912–1929 | label = [[Okeh Records|Okeh]], [[Vocalion Records|Vocalion]] | associated_acts = [[Clarence Williams (musician)|Clarence Williams]], Sam Gray | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Virginia Liston''' (1890 – June 1932) was an [[United States|American]] [[classic female blues]] and [[jazz]] [[singing|singer]]. She spent most of her career in [[Black people|black]] [[vaudeville]]. Liston recorded "You Can Dip Your Bread In My Gravy, But You Can't Have None Of My Chops," and "Just Take One Long Last Lingering Look." She worked with her then husband, Samuel H. Gray, billed as '''Liston And Liston,''' and also alongside [[Clarence Williams (musician)|Clarence Williams]]. In the latter context, she sang with both the Clarence Williams Blue Five on "You've Got The Right Key, But The Wrong Keyhole," and "Early In The Morning"; and the Clarence Williams Washboard Band on "Cushion Foot Stomp," and "P.D.Q. Blues."{{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://www.thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1950.html |title=The 50s and earlier |publisher=The Dead Rock Stars Club |date= |accessdate=2013-09-29}} ==Biography== Little detail is known about Liston's childhood.{{cite web|url=http://www.redhotjazz.com/virginialiston.html |title=Virginia Liston |publisher=Redhotjazz.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-29}} She made her start in show business circa 1912 in either [[Philadelphia]] or [[Washington, D.C.]]{{cite book | first= Scott | last= Yarrow | year= 2008 | title= The Jazz Singers: The Ultimate Guide | edition= 1st | publisher= Backbeat Books | location= Milwaukee | isbn= 978-0-87930-825-4 | page= 137}} In 1920 she was married to a fellow entertainer, Sam Gray, and [[concert tour|toured]] with him as part of a husband and wife act on the [[Theater Owners Bookers Association|T.O.B.A.]] circuit, billed as Liston and Liston. The billing was unusual, but because Liston was better known than Gray, he took her surname. In January 1924 they [[sound recording and reproduction|recorded]] one [[single (music)|single]] together. However, by 1925 they had [[divorce]]d. Liston met [[Clarence Williams (musician)|Clarence Williams]] in the early part of the 1920s, and he first recorded with her on [[Okeh Records]] in September 1923. Thirty six tracks were released in Liston's name up to 1926, on both Okeh and [[Vocalion Records]]. The most noteworthy of those releases were those recorded by Liston and Williams' Blue Five, who in those days included [[Louis Armstrong]] and [[Sidney Bechet]] in their number. By 1927 Liston had made her final recording session. In conjunction with the Clarence Williams Washboard Band, she recorded "Cushion Foot Stomp," and "P.D.Q. Blues". Her song, "You Don't Know My Mind Blues," was credited to the [[songwriter|songwriting]] team of Gray, Liston and Williams.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/song/you-dont-know-my-mind-blues-mt0006211182 |title=You Don't Know My Mind Blues - Doc Watson | Listen, Appearances, Song Review |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-09-29}} Several of her songs contained [[sexual innuendo]]. In 1926, in a song that she wrote herself, Liston opined her "Rolls Royce Papa" had a ''"bent piston rod."''{{cite book | first= John Alfred | last= Heitmann | year= 2009 | title= The Automobile and American Life | edition= 1st | publisher= McFarland & Company Inc. | location= Jefferson, North Carolina | isbn= 0786440139 | page= 115}} In 1929 Liston remarried and announced her retirement from [[show business]]. She duly relocated to [[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]], [[Missouri]] and worked for her local church.{{cite web|author=Uncle Dave Lewis |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/virginia-liston-mn0000810022 |title=Virginia Liston | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-09-29}} She died, from causes unknown, in June 1932 in St. Louis. All her recordings have been made available by [[Document Records]] (see below). ==Discography== *''Virginia Liston, Vol. 1: 1923-1924'' (2000) - [[Document Records|Document]] *''Virginia Liston, Vol. 2: 1924-1926 / Lavinia Turner'' (2000) - Document{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/virginia-liston-mn0000810022/discography |title=Virginia Liston | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date=2000-09-07 |accessdate=2013-09-29}} ==See also== *[[List of classic female blues singers]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.redhotjazz.com/virginialiston.html Biography and discography] {{Authority control|VIAF=19868077}} {{Persondata | NAME =Liston, Virginia | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[classic female blues]] and [[jazz]] singer | DATE OF BIRTH = 1890 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = June 1932 | PLACE OF DEATH =[[St. Louis, Missouri|St. Louis]], United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Liston, Virginia}} [[Category:1890 births]] [[Category:1932 deaths]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American female singers]] [[Category:American jazz singers]] [[Category:Songwriters from Missouri]] [[Category:Classic female blues singers]] [[Category:Musicians from St. Louis, Missouri]] [[Category:Place of birth missing]]
